newsitem.title: POLAND: CLOUDS MAY FORM OVER ZLOTY NEXT WEEK TRADERS SAY.
newsitem.headline: CLOUDS MAY FORM OVER ZLOTY NEXT WEEK TRADERS SAY.

text.p: Polish markets could be headed into rough waters next week as unsettled foreign investors ponder whether to slim zloty positions amid a ballooning current account deficit, dealers said on Friday.
This week dealers received mixed signals from foreigners, some of whom had sold short-term Polish papers over the last few days, worried that the zloty would weaken over time.

"Some foreigners have been slowly closing positions over the week, while others are asking about (buying) T-bills, to take advantage of the zloty's recent fall," said Piotr Bednarek, senior dealer at ING Bank in Warsaw.

As a result of the withdrawal, which has so far been confined to short-term instruments and spared longer-term bonds, the zloty fell about half a percentage point against the basket of currencies this week.

Some said foreigners were discouraged by a statement made by deputy central banker Witold Kozinski this week, who signalled that a Czech-style financial crisis may be further down the road for Poland if it failed to balance its budget in 1998, which the government later said was impossible.

"This is a signal that the ice may still be thin underneath Poland's macro reforms and the market should pay attention to these extreme statements as they don't come from an extreme man," David Mars, head of Emerging Europe and Africa Economic Research at SBC Warburg in London, said earlier this week.

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) backed up Kozinski with a strong worded statement of its own, which called for a balanced budget by 1999 and an immediate tightening of the country's already restricitive monetary policy.

Finance Minister Marek Belka tried to soothe investors reassuring monetary tightening and planned 1998 deficit reduction were sufficient to prevent the external deficit from reaching critical levels next year.

Dealers said however the zloty, which on Friday found balance at about one percent above the parity rate, could be in for a rough ride if further waves of foreign withdrawal hit the foreign exchange market next week.

"Buyers and sellers are at equal strength now and the zloty is range bound...but its seems that the zloty's downside could be more vulnerable in days to come," said Mateusz Bienek, forex dealer at Societe Generale in Warsaw.
On Friday the zloty was fixed at an average of one percent from the weighted dollar and mark parity rates, weaker than last Friday's 1.49 percent fix.
Dealers said the zloty would probably not be under downward pressure from the start of next week, but said that a rise above one percent from parity could set off more foreign sales of Polish paper.
Dealers said Polish T-bill yields would continue to rise at next Monday's 1.1 billion zloty primary auction amid small interest from both domestic players and foreigners.
They expected the 52-week T-bill yield to rise to 21.70 percent from Wednesday's 21.67 and the maximum to about 21.73.
"This week's statements were definitely not optimistic about Poland's longer term outlook, which should be reflected in higher yields on Monday," said Wojciech Labryga, dealer at Bank Slaski SA.
Dealers said the 13-week and 26-week yields would also rise by about five basis points from 21.00 and 21.49 percent respectively at the last primary tender.
